results.byline: By Emily Cochrane, Jim Tankersley and Lisa Friedman
results.title: Manchin, in Reversal, Agrees to Quick Action on Climate and Tax Plan
results.abstract: The West Virginia Democrat, a holdout on his party’s domestic agenda, said the package would reduce inflation, a concern he had cited in rejecting it just weeks ago.

media.caption: “Rather than risking more inflation with trillions in new spending, this bill will cut the inflation taxes Americans are paying,” Senator Joe Manchin III said in a statement on Wednesday.
media.copyright: Pete Marovich for The New York Times

media.caption: Carroll O’Connor, who played Archie Bunker, in 1971.

results.adx_keywords: Bacteria;Coccidioidomycosis (Valley Fever);Centers for Disease Control and Prevention;Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas;Gulf Coast (US);Mississippi;United States
results.title: Potentially Deadly Bacteria Detected in U.S. Soil for First Time
results.abstract: The bacteria, Burkholderia pseudomallei, was found along the Gulf Coast region of Southern Mississippi. Previously, it had been detected in parts of Asia and Australia.
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
geo_facet: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

media.caption: The Burkholderia pseudomallei bacteria, which can cause melioidosis, a rare and sometimes deadly disease long thought to be confined to tropical climates.
media.copyright: Dr. Todd Parker/U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, via Associated Press

results.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Luke Broadwater
results.title: ‘Kind of Wild/Creative’: Emails Shed Light on Trump Fake Electors Plan
results.abstract: Previously undisclosed communications among Trump campaign aides and outside advisers provide new insight into their efforts to overturn the election in the weeks leading to Jan. 6.
org_facet: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack

media.caption: One Arizona Republican involved in the effort to reverse the election outcome advocated keeping a key element of the strategy quiet “so we can try to ‘surprise’ the Dems and media with it” on Jan. 6, 2021.
media.copyright: Ash Ponders for The New York Times

results.title: OAN, a Dependable Trump Promoter, Faces a ‘Death Blow’
results.abstract: After Verizon drops the network at the end of this week, OAN’s cable TV audience will shrink dramatically.

media.caption: One America News’s headquarters in San Diego. The cable network will soon have lost its presence in some 20 million homes.

results.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Glenn Thrush
results.title: Justice Dept. Asking Witnesses About Trump in Its Jan. 6 Investigation
results.abstract: Federal prosecutors sought information about the former president’s role in the efforts to overturn the election as the inquiry accelerates.
org_facet: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack

media.caption: Even as the Jan. 6 committee has helped establish former President Donald J. Trump’s role in parts of the push to overturn his election loss, the Justice Department has been largely silent about whether it would weigh potential charges against him.
media.copyright: Kenny Holston for The New York Times

results.title: He Built a Home to Survive a Civil War. Tragedy Found Him Anyway.
results.abstract: C. Wesley Morgan once believed that the place he built, which included a 2,000-square-foot bunker, was the safest house in Kentucky.

media.caption: The mansion belonging to C. Wesley Morgan, a former Kentucky state representative.
media.copyright: Luke Sharrett for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: United States Politics and Government;Television;Trump, Donald J;Fox News Channel
results.title: Fox News snubbed Trump’s speech, in what’s becoming a pattern.
results.abstract: The network devoted little airtime to the speech on Tuesday by a former president its hosts often defend. Notably, it did go live with Mike Pence’s address.

media.caption: Former President Donald J. Trump gave the keynote speech at the America First Policy Institute Summit on Tuesday, but Fox News did not broadcast it live.

results.title: Senate Passes $280 Billion Industrial Policy Bill to Counter China
results.abstract: The bipartisan vote reflected a rare consensus in the otherwise polarized Congress in favor of investing federal resources into a broad industrial policy to counter China.

media.caption: A semiconductor production facility in Beijing. The issue of commercial and military competition with China — and the promise of thousands of new American jobs — has brought Democrats and Republicans together.

results.title: DNA Researchers Name the Somerton Man, Australia’s 73-Year-Old Cold Case
results.abstract: Sleuths amateur and professional alike have been puzzled for years by the discovery in 1948 of an unidentified man’s body slumped by a sea wall near Adelaide. The South Australian police have not verified the new finding.

media.caption: Pallbearers carrying the exhumed remains of the so-called Somerton Man last year in Adelaide, Australia.

results.title: The Case of the $5,000 Springsteen Tickets
results.abstract: Triumphant fans showed up in Ticketmaster’s queue with special codes, only to encounter its “dynamic pricing” system. Was the Boss OK with that?

results.abstract: They contain the food additive titanium dioxide, which is in thousands of food products. Here’s what we learned about its safety.

results.title: He’s Baseball’s Only Mud Supplier. It’s a Job He May Soon Lose.
results.abstract: Jim Bintliff collects the Delaware River mud that is smeared on Major League baseballs to make them less slippery. But that tradition is in jeopardy.

media.caption: Jim Bintliff and his family have been selling Delaware River mud to Major League Baseball for decades. Here, he fills a bucket in New Jersey.
media.copyright: Hannah Beier for The New York Times

results.title: Joni Mitchell Reclaims Her Voice at Newport
results.abstract: The singer-songwriter’s surprise return to the stage at the folk festival she first played in 1967 was an act of bravery, joy and reinterpretation.

media.caption: After a 2015 brain aneurysm, Joni Mitchell had to learn how to sing and play guitar again. She did both onstage at the Newport Folk Festival on Sunday, stunning the crowd and the fellow musicians onstage.

results.title: Do Eye Creams Actually Work for Wrinkles?
results.abstract: Look for a few key ingredients in skin care products if you want to deal with wrinkles — but no product will keep your face crease-free.

media.copyright: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Vitamin D;Osteoporosis;Bones;Bone Fractures;Preventive Medicine;Clinical Trials;Research;Steven R. Cummings;Clifford Rosen;New England Journal of Medicine
results.title: Study Finds Another Condition That Vitamin D Pills Do Not Help
results.abstract: The vitamin pills do not prevent bone fractures in most people or protect against many other diseases, adding to questions about medical guidance many now take for granted.

media.caption: A study of nearly 26,000 people who were assigned to take vitamin D each day found the vitamin had no effect, even among people who had low vitamin D levels or osteoporosis.

results.adx_keywords: Movies;Actors and Actresses;Content Type: Personal Profile;Writing and Writers;Novak, B J
results.title: B.J. Novak Went to Texas Looking for ‘Vengeance’ and Found America
results.abstract: The first film from a former star of “The Office” is a dark comedy about life in a nation that’s not as divided as we might think.

media.caption: “I thought that these huge dudes with beards and pickup trucks would be very suspicious of a Hollywood blue-state guy, and I found the exact opposite,” B.J. Novak said of his research trips to Texas.
media.copyright: Erik Tanner for The New York Times
